April 15, 2007: Fiction
NINETEEN MINUTES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $26.95.) The aftermath of a high
school shooting reveals the fault lines in a small New Hampshire town.
OBSESSION, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $26.95.) The psychologist-
detective Alex Delaware investigates what seems to be a deathbed confession of
murder.
THE ALIBI MAN, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $26.) A disgraced former policewoman
investigates a murder linked to a group of wealthy Palm Beach men.
WHITETHORN WOODS, by Maeve Binchy. (Knopf, $25.95.) A proposed highway
threatens the existence of a religious shrine in a rural Irish village.
FOR A FEW DEMONS MORE, by Kim Harrison. (Eos/HarperCollins, $21.95.) A
witch owns an ancient artifact that may stop a serial killer or ignite a gang war.
ABSOLUTE FEAR, by Lisa Jackson. (Kensington, $19.95.) A New Orleans
detective tracks a serial killer somehow linked to an abandoned asylum.
SHOPAHOLIC & BABY, by Sophie Kinsella. (Dial, $24.) Becky is pregnant, and
the obstetrician turns out to be her husband’s ex-girlfriend.
STEP ON A CRACK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) A detective raising 10 children alone must rescue 34 high-level hostages.
THE DOUBLE BIND, by Chris Bohjalian. (Shaye Areheart, $25.) A young woman
who works at a homeless shelter struggles to understand the mysterious
photographs taken by a recently deceased resident.
SISTERS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) After a family tragedy, four sisters
with very different lives decide to share a Manhattan brownstone.
DADDY’S GIRL, by Lisa Scottoline. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) A law professor
caught in a prison riot must defend herself when she is unjustly accused of
murder.
BURNING BRIGHT, by Tracy Chevalier. (Dutton, $24.95.) In Georgian London,
the poet William Blake befriends two neighborhood chldren.
HUNTER’S MOON, by Randy Wayne White. (Putnam, $24.95.) Doc Ford helps a
former president secretly investigate his wife’s death in a suspicious accident.
THE WATCHMAN, by Robert Crais. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A former Los
Angeles police officer becomes the bodyguard of a troubled heiress marked for
death.
HEART-SHAPED BOX, by Joe Hill. (Morrow, $24.95.) An aging rock star who
April 15, 2007
Non-Fiction
A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing
spree and his return to humanity.
GRACE (EVENTUALLY), by Anne Lamott. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Essays about
faith and forgiveness.
IN AN INSTANT, by Lee and Bob Woodruff. (Random House, $25.95.) The
aftermath of the ABC co-anchor’s traumatic brain injury in Iraq in 2006.
HOW DOCTORS THINK, by Jerome Groopman. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) A doctor
and New Yorker staff writer describes how doctors arrive at diagnoses.
I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at
aging from a novelist and screenwriter (“When Harry Met Sally”).
INFIDEL, by Ayaan Hirsi Ali. (Free Press, $26.) A memoir by the Somali-born
advocate for Muslim immigrant women.
THE AUDACITY OF HOPE, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.) The Illinois junior
senator proposes that Americans move beyond their political divisions.
THE GOD DELUSION, by Richard Dawkins. (Houghton Mifflin, $27.) An Oxford
scientist asserts that belief in God is irrational.
THE NEW AMERICAN STORY, by Bill Bradley. (Random House, $25.95.) The
former Democratic senator and presidential candidate presents a liberal-centrist
agenda.
THE HARDCORE DIARIES, by Mick Foley. (World Wrestling Entertainment/
Pocket, $24.) The former professional wrestling champion discusses his fame and
his life at World Wrestling Entertainment.
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $29.95 and $21.95.) A newspaper
columnist and his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) A
columnist for The Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
SOMEBODY’S GOTTA SAY IT, by Neal Boortz (HC/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A
radio talk-show host discusses government, povertyand other topics.
SECOND CHANCE, by Zbigniew Brzezinski. (Basic, $26.95.) The former National
Security adviser discusses how America can regain the global power and prestige
squandered by its three post-cold-war presidents.
RELIGIOUS LITERACY, by Stephen Prothero. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.)
